channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Biden says US troops may stay past withdrawal deadline
item.description: President Biden says he may keep forces there beyond August to help evacuate US citizens.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: 'Many here will be deeply fearful for their future'
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports from the heart of Kabul during the unfolding crisis in Afghanistan.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Rescue efforts continue in Les Cayes
item.description: The death toll from the 7.2-magnitude quake is now over 2,000, with many still missing in towns like Les Cayes.

item.title: Washington DC: Active bomb threat near US Capitol
item.description: US Capitol Police are negotiating with the driver of a suspicious vehicle on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Canadian soldier faces jail over feeding cannabis cupcakes to troops
item.description: A Canadian bombardier fed cannabis cakes to troops during a drill involving guns and live ammunition.

item.title: Belgium stabbing suspect won’t be charged over unborn baby’s death
item.description: A man in Belgium is charged with allegedly stabbing his partner, but not her unborn baby's death.

item.title: Russia names Golos monitor as 'foreign agent' ahead of election
item.description: Golos has vowed to continue its work ahead of parliamentary elections in a month's time.

item.title: Chip shortage: Toyota to cut global production by 40%
item.description: The world's biggest carmaker will cut output in September, while VW warns it may have to make further cuts.

item.title: Covid-19: Mississippi quarantines 20,000 pupils at start of new school year
item.description: Schools around the US are seeing Covid-19 outbreaks within days of starting the new academic year.

item.title: Afghanistan: Pakistan fences off from Afghan refugees
item.description: Islamabad says it cannot accept any more Afghans fleeing Taliban rule, despite UN pleas.

item.title: Facebook reveals most-seen posts are inane questions, not politics
item.description: "Does sugar go in spaghetti?" is among the US's top posts, as Facebook battles right-wing content claims.

item.title: The villages cut off from help by Haiti earthquake
item.description: The tremor razed their homes, but these survivors could still die for a lack of basic supplies.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Algeria: The forest fires that led to an artist's lynching
item.description: When Djamel Ben Ismail went to fight forest fires in Algeria, his life was cut short by a raging mob.

item.title: Tigray crisis: Ethiopian teenagers become pawns in propaganda war
item.description: The BBC is told they were forced to fight for Tigray's rebels, but were words put into their mouths?

item.title: Brazil hopes the world will get a taste for its favourite spirit
item.description: With domestic sales of cachaça falling last year, Brazilian producers want to export more.

item.title: The little-known human stories behind emoji designs
item.description: The surprising story of how some tiny characters ended up on billions of smartphone keyboards.

item.title: How latte art in South Africa led to a job from hell in Oman
item.description: A South African barista was offered a dream opportunity in Oman but unknowingly signed away his freedoms.

item.title: Afghan interpreter begs PM Boris Johnson for 'pathway to safety'
item.description: Ahmed (not his real name), who worked for the British Army, begs the UK to evacuate him and his family.

item.title: Afghanistan: Joe Biden said chaos was 'inevitable'
item.description: In an interview with ABC, Joe Biden said nobody could have anticipated the speed of the Taliban takeover.

item.title: Can the Paralympics bring lasting change?
item.description: A campaign gets underway to try to improve the lives of the world's 1.2bn disabled people.

item.title: Afghanistan: Fatalities as shots fired at flag protest in Jalalabad
item.description: Protesters took to the streets of Jalalabad holding aloft the country's national flag.

item.title: Taliban have been looking for me, says ex-Afghanistan bank governor
item.description: Militants have been knocking on the doors of places he used to live, Ajmal Ahmady says.

item.title: Afghanistan: A woman's story of life under the Taliban in 1999
item.description: Taliban rule in 1999 - an Afghan woman recalls the day her father disappeared.

item.title: ‘Don’t forget the 500,000 internally displaced Afghans’ - UNCHR
item.description: Do not forget the 500,000 internally displaced people, the UNHCR representative to Afghanistan says.

item.title: Afghanistan evacuations: Woman on trip back to Kabul describes fleeing city
item.description: A councillor who was visiting family in the country she had left aged three tells of her evacuation.

item.title: IMF suspends Afghanistan's access to funds
item.description: The move follows the Taliban's takeover, and lack of global agreement over who now governs Afghanistan.

item.title: 'It was very emotional on the plane out of Afghanistan'
item.description: Afghan businesswoman Hassina Syed speaks of her relief at getting out on a British military plane.

item.title: Veteran silences MPs with powerful Afghan speech
item.description: Tory MP Tom Tugendhat speaks of the anger, grief and rage of veterans at the "abandonment" of Afghanistan.
